Award.AwardTitle: Optical and Radio Uniquely High-Resolution Eclipse Coronal Studies
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Principal Investigator (PI) plans to observe two solar eclipses in 2012 that will occur over the USA and Australia. For the 20 May 2012 annular solar eclipse over the western USA, the PI plans to map long wavelength active-region radio emission at 91 centimeter and other wavelengths. For the 13 November 2012 total solar eclipse over Australia, he intends to make optical spectrographic observations of the white-light, green-line, and red-line corona and to work with highly processed images to bring out detail and contrast. These processed images promise to improve measurements of the lifetimes and motions of coronal plumes and other coronal features.

The PI's solar corona observations will be applied to the study of other stars, many of whose coronae are currently being observed in x-rays by the Chandra satellite observatory. The PI notes that his high-resolution studies of flaring and active regions at long radio wavelengths should give information potentially useful for space weather predictions. The PI asserts that his expeditions to study the solar corona during eclipses have been a major part of the success of the Williams College Department of Astronomy in attracting and training undergraduate students in the physical sciences. The PI has widely disseminated his past research through technical journals, textbooks, National Geographic television programming, DVDs, and online streaming educational videos, and he will continue these efforts. Eclipses are of widespread public interest and provide unique opportunities for public education about astronomy and solar physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For the total eclipse of 2012, based on photographs taken at our sites in Queensland, Australia, we were able to measure motions in the solar corona, which is uniquely visible from Earth during totality, with computer analysis transforming several dozen of our images into a high-dynamic-range and high-contrast composite.  We were able to compare and combine our composite image with one we assembled from another site, in the Pacific, and to assemble a wide range of spacecraft observations from the same day to lilnk and integrate all possible observations related to the event.  We measured a speed for a coronal mass ejection of the type that sometimes hits the Earth and satellites around it, improving our understanding of such eruptions and their propagation through interplanetary space, an important set of things to understand because when such eruptions hit Earth's atmosphere they can cause massive disruptions of satellites or ground power lines.  We also continued our measurements of trends in the million-degree temperature of the corona with spectra that we obtain at all eclipses. We are following the corona configuration, dynamics, and temperature through the sunspot cycle. We reported on these results at meetings of the American Astronomical Society and its Solar Physics Division, at a meeting of the American Geophysical Union, and with a major article that appeared in 2015 in The Astrophysical Journal, the world's major astronomy journal.

For the annular eclipse of 2012 (an annular eclipse is when the Moon in its orbit is farther than average from the Earth so that it doesn't quite cover the Earth even when it passes directly in front of the disk, leaving an annulus of everyday sunlight) , observed with the National Radio Astronomy Observatory's huge assembly of radio telescopes in New Mexico known as the Jansky Very Large Array, we have thus far been able to show the suitability of the configuration for high-resolution observations of solar active regions in the radio spectrum, as the moon's edge first covers and then uncovers the solar active regions, for comparison with high-resolution ground-based and satellite observations.  

In both cases, we have made progress in our abilities, plans, and preparations for the total solar eclipse of August 21, 2017, during which the path of totality, about 60 miles wide, will cross the continental United States from northwest (Oregon) to southeast (South Carolina), the first such totality path in 99 years. The whole United States will enjoy at least a 60% partial eclipse, so there will be widespread interest of the general public.

We also provided training of a variety of students: 8 undergraduates participated on site at the 2012 annular eclipse.  One undergraduate and two graduate students were trained in total eclipse observations by participation in our expedition to Queensland, Australia.
